newsitem.title: MONGOLIA: Mongolia aims to cut 1997 inflation to 35 pct.
newsitem.headline: Mongolia aims to cut 1997 inflation to 35 pct.

text.p: The Mongolian government plans to cut annual inflation to below 35 percent next year, down from about 50 percent this year, Minister of Finance Tsagaan said on Friday.

"Preliminary figures on annual inflation this year are 45-50 percent, and it has been planned that this will go down to 35 percent in 1997," Tsagaan told a news conference, adding that he hoped the rate would fall even lower.
Mongolia's annual inflation in 1995 was 53.1 percent, down from 66.3 percent in 1994. The government had earlier set a target of less than 30 percent for inflation this year.
The government would impose a tight monetary policy to try to stabilise the economy, Tsagaan said.
The steps in economic reform adopted by the new government, elected in July, had been taken in September by liberalising energy prices without an increase in salaries, he said.
